questions.text: Which of the following is the site of placement of the V4 chest lead while recording an ECG?

choices.text: At the midclavicular line in the fifth intercostal space
In the fifth intercostal space just to the left of the sternum
At the anterior axillary line in the fifth intercostal space
In the fourth intercostal space just to the left of the sternum

questions.solution:
While recording an ECG, the V4 chest lead is placed at the midclavicular line in the fifth intercostal space.

The site of placement of the chest leads is as follows:

V1: 4th intercostal space, right of the sternum 
V2: 4th intercostal space, left of the sternum (Option D)
V3: 5th intercostal space, left of the sternum (Option B)
V4: 5th intercostal space, centered on clavicle
V5: 5th intercostal space, left of V4
V6: 5th intercostal space, under the left arm

An ECG can be recorded by using an active electrode that is connected to an electrode at zero potential (unipolar recording) or by using two active electrodes (bipolar recording).

For unipolar recording, six chest leads or precordial leads (V1–V6) and three limb leads (VR-right arm, VL-left arm, and VF-left foot) are used. Because the heart surfaces are close to the chest wall, the chest lead mainly records the electrical potential of the cardiac musculature immediately beneath it. Therefore, relatively minute abnormalities in the heart muscles can cause marked changes in the ECGs recorded from individual chest leads.

In some patients, posterior leads may be placed on the same horizontal plane as V4 to facilitate the detection of acute posterolateral infarction (V7 in midaxillary line; V8 in posterior axillary line; and V9 in posterior scapular line).

Right chest leads (V3R and V6R) can help enhance the detection of right ventricular involvement in patients with inferior infarction.

Related Pearl: ECG Leads

LA – Left arm: RA – Right arm: LL – Left leg: LF – Left foot

  • Limb leads measure the electrical activity in the frontal plane
  • Chest leads measure the electrical activity in the horizontal plane


Limb Lead Location Augmented limb leads Location Chest leads Location
+ -
I LA

  RA aVF LF +ve V1 4th intercostal space. just to the right of the sternum
II LL

  RA aVL LA +ve V2 4th intercostal space. just to the left of the sternum
III LL

 LA  aVR RA +ve V3 midway between V2 and V4
  V4 Midclavicular line. fifth intercostal
V5 Anterior axillary line, same level as V4
V6 Midaxillary line, the same level as V4 and V5

questions.text: Which of the following is the electrocardiograph changes seen in early stages of acute pericarditis?

choices.text: ST-segment depression with flat T waves
ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression

questions.solution:
ECG showing diffuse ST-segment elevation with PR segment depression is seen in early stages of acute pericarditis.

The ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolves through four stages:

  • Stage 1- Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression. 
  • Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal
  • Stage 3 - Diffuse T wave inversion
  • Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months

Echocardiography findings are usually normal or may show evidence of a pericardial effusion. If abnormal, regular echocardiographic monitoring is recommended.

The ECG below shows acute pericarditis causing diffuse ST-segment elevations in leads I, II, aVF, and V2 to V6, with reciprocal ST depressions in lead aVR.

Other options:

Option A: ST-segment depression with flat T waves are seen in hypokalemia. Prolongation of QT interval is also seen.

ECG given below shows ST depression and broad flat T waves seen in hypokalemia.

Option B: Electrical alternans of P, QRS, and T waves are seen in cardiac tamponade.

ECG given below shows electrical alterans seen in cardiac tamponade.

Option D: Tall, tented T waves are seen in hyperkalemia.

ECG given below shows tall peaked T waves seen in hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency room complaining his heart is pounding and that he is going to die. The emergency physician orders an ECG. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall infarction.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: All of the following are true about the U wave in an ECG except?

choices.text: Normally deflection is ≤1 mm and usually has the same polarity as the T wave
Prominent U waves are a marker of increased susceptibility to torsades de pointes
Abnormal increase in amplitude is seen in hyperkalemia
Occurs due to repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

questions.solution:
An abnormal increase in the amplitude of the U wave is seen in hypokalemia and not hyperkalemia.

U waves in the ECG represent the ventricular repolarization, particularly of myocytes with long action potentials (option D). The U wave is a small, rounded deflection ≤1 mm that occurs after the T wave. It usually has the same polarity as the T wave (option A). A very prominent U wave is considered a marker of increased susceptibility to torsades de pointes (option B). Abnormal increase in U-wave amplitude are most commonly due to drugs such as dofetilide, amiodarone, sotalol, and quinidine. It may also be seen in hypokalemia.

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the normal calibration of a typical ECG tracing?

choices.text: Horizontally, one large box corresponds to 0.4 seconds.
Horizontally, one small box corresponds to 0.02 seconds.
It is recorded at a speed of 25 millimeters per second.

questions.solution:
An ECG is recorded at the speed of 25 millimeters per second.

An electrocardiogram is a representation of electrical activity generated by the heart and is recorded on graph paper that is divided into 1-mm2 gridlike boxes. A typical ECG is run at a speed of 25 millimeters per second, although faster speeds are sometimes used.

On the horizontal axis, one small box is 1mm and 5 such boxes make up a large box which is 5mm. When the recording speed is 25 mm/s or 25 small boxes/second, the time represented by one small box is 1/25 second. Thus, horizontally

  • 1 small box = 0.04 seconds (Option C)
  • 1 large box = 5 x 0.04 seconds = 0.2 seconds (Option B)

On the vertical axis representing the amplitude of the deflections, 1 small box is 1mm and 10 such boxes represent 1 millivolt. So, 1 small box represents 1/10 = 0.1 millivolt. (Option A). Calibration is often confirmed using the reference pulse tracing that is present in ECG tracings.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are correct with respect to the cardiac cycle, heart sounds, and the waveforms seen on the ECG?

1) Timing of S1 heart sound corresponds temporally to the occurrence of QRS wave in ECG

2) Timing of S2 heart sound corresponds temporally to the end of T wave in ECG

3) 'v' wave of JVP mirrors the rise in atrial pressure before the tricuspid valve opens

4) The ‘c’ wave of JVP is seen during the first phase of the ventricular diastole.
questions.solution:
The statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct.

As clear from Wigger's diagram below, S1 corresponds the timing of S1 heart sound corresponds temporally to the occurrence of QRS wave in ECG.

Similarly, the timing of the S2 heart sound corresponds to the end of the T wave in ECG. 

The statement D is incorrect as the ‘c’ wave of JVP is seen during the isovolumetric contraction (with all valves closed) phase when the ventricular muscle continues to contract. 

The Cardiac Cycle:

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to the momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with the 'a' wave in JVP.

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

Related Pearl: Heart sounds

Heart Sound

Frequency

Duration

Associated Event

ECG Correlation

S1

25-45 Hz

0.15 sec

Closure of AV Valves-Onset of Ventricular systole

Later half of R wave

S2

50 Hz

0.12 sec

Closure of Semilunar Valves-Onset of ventricular diastole

Later half of T wave

S3

Low

0.1 sec

First rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole

Between the T and P wave

S4

Below 20 Hz

0.1 sec

Last rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole due to atrial contraction

Following P wave

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with dizziness and breathing difficulty to the emergency department. Vitals are significant for a BP of 100/70mm of Hg and a pulse rate of 110 bpm. Her heart sounds are muffled. The ECG tracing is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia. This along with the patient's symptoms of muffled heart sounds, breathlessness, and hypotension points to a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Pulsus paradoxus is typically associated with cardiac tamponade.

Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. In cardiac tamponade, the ventricles are covered by an incompressible pericardial sac with increased pressure in the pericardial sac. Increased blood flows into the right ventricle during inspiration causes the interventricular septum to bulge into the left ventricle, which in turn causes a reduction in left ventricular volume, stroke volume, and arterial blood pressure. Severe cases may show weakening or disappearance of arterial pulse on palpation during inspiration.

Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Severe obstructive lung disease
  • Hemorrhagic shock

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space causing raised intra-pericardial pressure. This results in poor ventricular filling and a fall in cardiac output. This may be acute following trauma or as a complication of an invasive diagnostic or therapeutic procedure. Subacute cardiac tamponade occurs over days to weeks and can be associated with neoplastic, uremic, or idiopathic pericarditis.

Symptoms of cardiac tamponade include dyspnea, chest discomfort or fullness, peripheral edema, and fatigue. Examination findings are:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus

ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, it leads to an increased amplitude deflection on the ECG, whereas, a lower amplitude deflection is seen when the heart moves away from the chest wall.

The echocardiography shows a swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of heart chambers, IVC plethora, and respiratory variation in volumes and flows.

Other options:

Option A: Pulsus bisferiens also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option B: Pulsus parvus et tardus refers to a weak pulse (parvus), which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus) seen in aortic stenosis.

Option D: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

 

Related Pearl: Causes of Pulsus Paradoxus

Physiological causes

Obesity

Pregnancy

Cardiovascular causes

Cardiac tamponade – most common cause

Constrictive pericarditis ( in 1/3rd cases )

Massive pulmonary embolism

Severe CCF

Hypovolemic shock

Respiratory causes

Severe obstructive lung disease

Acute severe asthma

Severe emphysema

Tension pneumothorax

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with complaints of palpitations and syncope. He has a history of inferior-wall myocardial infarction a year ago. The ECG strip obtained during his admission is given below. What is the long-term treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on his ECG findings, this patient is suffering from symptomatic (palpitations, syncope) Mobitz Type II AV block. The definitive long-term treatment is, therefore, a permanent pacemaker. 

Mobitz Type II AV block is characterized by:

  • a constant PR interval
  • some P waves not be followed by QRS complexes

According to the rhythm strip (Lead II) of the ECG shown, the patient is experiencing a 3:2 AV block which is then progressing to a 2:1 AV block.

This patient is also suffering from a right bundle branch block (RBBB) as indicated by the wide QRS complexes in leads V1, V2, and V3 ('M'-shaped). 

This patient with a history of ischemic heart disease (previous history of inferior-wall MI) and objective signs of Mobitz Type II AV block and RBBB will benefit most from a permanent pacemaker. 

In the ECG below, the blue arrows show some P waves that were not followed by QRS complexes. The missed QRS complex is pointed by the red arrow. The red box indicates the wide QRS complexes in leads V1, V2, and V3:

 

Other options:

Option A - Amiodarone, a class III anti-arrhythmic agent, is the drug of choice in the acute treatment as well as prevention of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. It is a rate-control medication. 

Options B and D - Pharmacologic interventions such as atropine and isoproterenol serve as short-term supplementary treatment options until a pacemaker can be installed or if the AV block is transient in nature. Even in such instances, a temporary transcutaneous pacemaker is preferred until a permanent device is available. 

Related Pearl: Indication for Pacemaker in AV Conduction Defects

  • In any patient with symptomatic bradycardia
  • Irreversible second- or third-degree AV bloc
  • Pacing in patients with asymptomatic AV block should be individualized

With acquired CHB

Left ventricular dysfunction and

Waking heart rates 40 beats/min.
  • Asymptomatic second-degree AV block of either type, if the block is demonstrated to be intra- or infra-His or is associated with a wide QRS complex
  • Neuromuscular diseases having a predilection for the conduction system, such as myotonic dystrophy and other muscular dystrophies, and Kearns-Sayre syndrome

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: An ECG showing S1Q3T3 changes is suggestive of which of the following?
questions.solution:
An ECG showing S1Q3T3 changes is most likely suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism (PE).

ECG changes in acute PE (shown below) are characterized by the classic S1Q3T3 changes, due to right ventricular strain and ischemia:

  • A prominent S wave in lead I (blue arrow)
  • Q wave in lead III (red arrow)
  • An inverted T wave in lead III (green arrow)

Other options: 

Option B: In patients with pleural effusion ECG appears normal or may show non-specific findings such as low voltage QRS, axis deviation, and/or electrical alternans.

Option C: ECG changes in acute pericarditis evolve through four stages:

  • Stage 1 - Generalized ST-segment elevation with upward concavity with reciprocal depressions only in aVR and V1 and PR segment depression. 
  • Stage 2 - The ST segments return to normal
  • Stage 3 - Diffuse T wave inversion
  • Stage 4 - ECG returns to normal in weeks or months

Option D: ECG changes in Tricuspid stenosis (TS) include tall, peaked P waves in lead II and prominent, upright P waves in V1.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His ECG is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature and the ECG are pointing towards the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate >100 bpm
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with >3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

MAT is characterised by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrhythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia has a rate of 150-200 bpm. It also has a regular rhythm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex. It can occur in a normal heart. The drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation has an irregularly irregular rhythm. The rate is >300 bpm. The 'P' wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter has a regular rhythm. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw-tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to result in the following ECG picture?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a left-axis deviation. Left bundle branch block, aortic valvular stenosis, and hypertension cause left ventricular hypertrophy leading to left-axis deviation in ECG. Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis causes right ventricular hypertrophy leads to a right-axis deviation and hence is unlikely to be associated with the above ECG.

In a given ECG, the axis can be calculated based on lead I, lead II, and aVF. The direction of vectors is decided based on the axis of the leads as shown below and whether the QRS complex in that lead has a positive or a negative deflection.

  • Since the lead I has a positive QRS wave, this vector lies in the region shaded blue below.
  • Since the lead II has a negative QRS wave, this vector lies in the region shaded yellow below.
  • Since the lead aVF has a negative QRS wave, this vector lies in the region shaded red below.

The summation of the above three vectors is represented by the cross-section of the shaded area common to all three leads. Thus the mean cardiac axis lies between -30º to -90º (area shaded in purple) and represents left-axis deviation.

The cardiac axis of the heart represents the mean QRS axis (direction of the mean depolarization vector). The normal adult QRS axis is directed downward and to the left, which is between -30 degrees and +100 degrees.

If the mean axis is:

  • More negative than –30 degrees- left axis deviation
  • More positive than +100 degrees- right axis deviation
  • Lies between -90 to +180 degrees- extreme axis deviation

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a syncopal episode. Additionally, he complains of palpitations that had started before the syncopal episode. His BP is 135/90 mm of Hg and a heart rate is 110 bpm. He recently had started taking azithromycin for an infection. Serum electrolytes are as shown below
Serum Electrolytes Values Normal Range
Sodium (mmol/L)  140  135-145 
Chloride (mmol/L)  100 95-105
Potassium (mmol/L)  3 3.5-5 
Bicarbonate (mmol/L)  21 18-22 

ECG findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the first line for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and ECG represent a case of torsades de pointes. Magnesium Sulphate is the first line of management in hemodynamically stable cases.

Torsades de pointes commonly present as syncope or chest pain. This patient's hypokalemia and use of azithromycin predispose him to develop symptomatic torsades de pointes.

Torsades de pointes means twisting of points, it implies twisting of the QRS complexes around the isoelectric line of the ECG. It is a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that is seen in patients with prolonged QT interval. 

A prolonged QT interval usually results from prolonged ventricular repolarization (lengthening of the T wave). A premature ventricular contraction falling in the elongated T wave can initiate torsades de Pointes.

The features of torsades de pointes are:

  • Polymorphic QRS complexes that change in amplitude (as seen in the image)
  • Cycle length gives an appearance of oscillations around the baseline
  • QT prolongation

Other options:

Options B & C - Procainamide and Ibutilide are used in the management of Wolff Parkinson White syndrome. 

Option D - Defibrillation is indicated only if the patient is hemodynamically unstable, or as a last resort.

Related Pearl: Etiology of Torsade De Pointes

Acquired prolongation of QT interval

Electrolyte abnormalities

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypocalcemia

Drugs

  • Antiarrhythmic drugs
    • Class IA: Quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide
    • Class III: Sotalol, amiodarone (QT prolongation common but torsade ventricular tachycardia is rare), ibutilide, dofetilide, almokalant
  • Antibiotics
    • Macrolides: Erythromycin, clarithromycin, azithromycin
    • Fluoroquinolones: Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin
    • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
    • Clindamycin
    • Pentamidine
    • Chloroquine
    • Antifungals: Ketoconazole, itraconazole
    • Antivirals
    • Antipsychotics
    • Antihistamines

Related Pearl: Drugs causing QT prolongation and torsades de pointes

Drugs Associated with QT Prolongation and Torsades de Pointes:

Antiarrhythmics:

  • Sotalol
  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

Antimicrobials:

  • Levofloxacin
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Gatifloxacin
  • Moxifloxacin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Erythromycin
  • Ketoconazole
  • Itraconazole
  • Rilpivirine

Antidepressants:

  • Amitriptyline
  • Desipramine
  • Imipramine
  • Doxepin
  • Fluoxetine
  • Sertraline
  • Venlafaxine

Antipsychotics:

  • Haloperidol
  • Droperidol
  • Quetiapine
  • Ziprasidone
  • Thioridazine

Others:

  • Cisapride
  • Sumatriptan
  • Zolmitriptan
  • Arsenic
  • Dolasetron
  • Methadone

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not seen in a patient with a Dextrocardia?

choices.text: Inverted P wave in lead I and lead aVL
Negative QRS comples in Lead I
Negative T wave in Lead I
Progressively increasing voltage across precordium in chest leads

questions.solution:
Progressively decreasing (not increasing) voltage across the precordium is seen in dextrocardia. This is because the heart is located on the right side, while the leads are placed on the left. Right-sided lead placement would show a normal progression.

Findings Suggestive of Dextrocardia

  • Inverted P waves in Lead I and aVL
  • Negative QRS complex and T wave in Lead I
    • (Lead I: inversion of all complexes, aka ‘global negativity’ i.e. inverted P wave, negative QRS, inverted T wave)
  • Progressively decreasing voltage across the precordium

 

ECG showing dextrocardia:

questions.text: Which of the following ECGs represents the Wenckebach phenomenon?
questions.solution:
ECG 4 showing a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex represents the Wenckebach phenomenon. It is also known as Mobitz type 1 and is a subtype of second-degree atrioventricular block.

ECG 1: Mobitz type 2 heart block
ECG 2: First-degree heart block
ECG 3: Complete heart block
ECG 4: Mobitz type 1 heart block

Second-degree heart block occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS and maybe of Mobitz type I or II.

Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach (ECG 4) occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex. This occurs because the atria are unable to conduct the electrical impulse to the ventricles. Patients are usually asymptomatic unless there is significant ventricular bradyarrhythmia. They also have irregular pulse rates. 

 

 

Mobitz type II block (ECG 1) is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. Bradyarrhythmias that cause syncope include those due to severe sinus node dysfunction and AV block (Mobitz type II block, complete AV block). Syncope due to bradycardia or asystole is referred to as Stokes-Adams attack.

The dropped QRS is marked in the image below:

Other options: 

ECG 2 shows a prolonged PR interval (> 0.2s) and equal RR intervals. This is indicative of first degree heart block.

ECG 3 shows the following findings:

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

This is seen in third-degree heart block/complete heart block.

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: A patient's ECG strip is given below. His cardiac output was found to be 4.8 L/min. What is the stroke volume?
questions.solution:
Cardiac output is calculated by the following formula -

Cardiac output = Heart rate x Stroke volume

The patient's cardiac output is 4.8L/min.

His heart rate can be calculated from the rhythm strip given i.e., HR = 300/number of large squares between consecutive beats. There are approximately 5 large boxes between beats in this ECG.

HR = 300/5 = 60 beats/min.

Therefore, the patient's stroke volume = CO/HR = 4.8L/min/60 beats/min = 0.08 L = 80ml

Related Pearl: Cardiac parameters

Parameter

Definition

Normal Value

Stroke Volume (SV)

Amount of blood ejected by each ventricle per stroke

70-90 ml

End-Diastolic volume (EDV)

Amount of blood in the ventricle at the end of diastole

130 ml

End-Systolic Volume

EDV-SV

~50 ml

Ejection Fraction

(SV/EDV) x100

55%-68%

Cardiac Output (CO)

SV x HR

~5 L/min

Cardiac Index

CO/BSA (m2)

3.2 L/min/m2

BSA - Body surface area

HR - Heart rate

questions.text: The ECG wave as shown in the image below is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
The above ECG wave characteristically depicts Digoxin effect.

Digoxin effect refers to the presence on the ECG of:

  • Downsloping ST depression with a characteristic “Salvador Dali sagging” or “Hockey Stick” appearance.
  • Flattened, inverted, or biphasic T waves.
  • Shortened QT interval.

Additional ECG Features:

  • Mild PR interval prolongation of up to 240ms (due to increased vagal tone).
  • Prominent U waves.
  • Peaking of the terminal portion of the T waves.
  • J point depression (usually in leads with tall R waves).

QRS complex / ST segment changes:

  • The morphology of the QRS complex / ST segment is variously described as either “slurred”, “sagging” or “scooped” and resembling either a “reverse tick”, “hockey stick” or “Salvador Dali’s moustache”.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and palpitations. ECG strip obtained is shown in the image below. His BP is 120/76 mm Hg. Vagal maneuvers were tried but failed. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
This ECG strip is suggestive of the AV nodal reentry (AVNRT) variant of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The drug of choice for the termination of PSVT is adenosine. 

PSVT spans a variety of tachycardia that differ based on the pathway of impulse conduction. They include AV node reentry, AV reentry via an accessory pathway, and atrial tachycardia. AVNRT is the most commonly seen pattern of PSVT in healthy adults, especially in women. This form of PSVT is due to the re-entry of the electrical impulse from the AV node to the right atrium via either of the 2 pathways (superior fast pathway and inferior slow pathway).

The given ECG strip shows changes suggestive of AV node reentry tachycardia based on the following findings-

  • Narrow QRS complex tachycardia (green arrows) at 150 bpm - indicative of a regular atrial rate (1:1 AV response). Heart rate is calculated by dividing 300 by the number of large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves. The ECG strip shows the presence of roughly 2 large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves, thereby making the HR ~150 bpm. 
  • No visible P waves - indicative of dual conduction pathways (slow and fast) that cause simultaneous atrial and ventricular activation.
  • The P wave may sometimes be seen at the end of the QRS complex as a pseudo-r' wave (V1) (black arrow) and pseudo-S wave (II, III, aVF) (blue arrows). 
 
 
Treatment - Since AVNRT depends on the functionality of the AV node, administering adenosine terminates most cases of tachycardia. This drug transiently blocks AV conduction by activating acetylcholine-sensitive K+ current in the atria, SAN, and AV nodes. These changes lead to a short action potential duration, hyperpolarization of the nodal tissues, and slowing of automaticity.
Intravenous verapamil or diltiazem can be used alternatively in patients who cannot tolerate adenosine.

questions.text: The electrocardiograph (ECG) of a patient with core body temperature of 85 °F is shown below. What is the hallmark of this patient's ECG marked by arrows in the image below?
questions.solution:
The hallmark of this patient's ECG is the Osborn J wave.

Hypothermia is defined as core body temperature is less than 95°F.

In the initial stages of hypothermia, as a reaction to the general stress, there is sinus tachycardia. As the temperature drops below 90°F, there is sinus bradycardia associated with prolongation of the PR interval, QRS complex, and QT interval progressively.

With temperature approaching 86°F, atrial ectopic activity is often noted and can progress to atrial fibrillation. It is at this level of hypothermia that many patients have Osborn waves that consist of an extra deflection at the end of the QRS complex. J waves occur when a heterogeneous distribution of potassium current enhances the activity of a transient outward potassium current in the heart, caused by low temperatures.

Osborn waves, also known as J waves, camel-hump waves, or hypothermic waves, are best seen in the inferior and lateral precordial leads. They become more prominent as the body temperature drops, and they regress gradually with rewarming.

A progressive widening of the QRS complex occurs when the temperature falls below 86°F, which is associated with an increased risk of ventricular fibrillation and asystole occurs when the temperature drops to about 60°F.

Other options:

Option A: Prominent U waves are seen in hypokalemia.

Option B: Tall peaked T waves are the first change in the ECG as the plasma potassium level rises.

Option C: ST segment elevation is seen in myocardial infarction.

questions.text: An elderly obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of severe chest pain for the last two hours. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left arm, nausea, and one episode of vomiting.  On examination, pulse rate is 58/min and BP is 90/60 mmHg. His ECG is shown below. Cardiac biomarkers showed elevated troponin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is inferior wall MI based on the given presentation of chest pain, bradycardia (pulse rate 58/min), hypotension (BP 90/60 mm Hg), elevated cardiac biomarkers, and ECG changes (ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, aVF, with reciprocal change in lead aVL). 

Inferior wall MI mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. While anterior infarction shows sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and hypertension), the inferior wall MI shows parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension).

The table below gives the localization of MI and probable vessel involved based on ECG findings.

Location of MI Leads Affected Vessel Involved
Anterior wall V2 to V4 Left Anterior Descending artery 
– Diagonal branch
Septal wall V1 and V2 Left Anterior Descending artery 
– Septal branch
Lateral wall I, aVL, V5, V6 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch
Inferior wall II, III, aVF Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch
Posterior wall V1 to V4 Left Coronary Artery (LCA)
– Circumflex branch

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)
– Posterior descending branch

Patients with pericarditis also present with severe chest pain and ST-segment elevations. However, this ST-segment elevation has upward concavity with depression of the PR segment.

An ECG showing pericarditis is given below.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following changes seen in hyperkalemia in ascending order of the potassium values in which they would be seen.
  1. Tall peaked T waves 
  2. Loss of P waves
  3. Widened QRS complex
  4. Sine wave pattern
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of changes is 

  1. Tall peaked T waves 
  2. Loss of P waves
  3. Widened QRS complex
  4. Sine wave pattern

Hyperkalemia is an increase in the levels of serum potassium >5.5 mM. It is a medical emergency and has to be treated when ECG changes are present or severe hyperkalemia (serum K >6.5) without ECG changes.  Features include cardiac arrhythmias which include sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation and asystole.

ECG shows tall and peaked T waves, widening of QRS complexes, loss of P waves and sine wave pattern.

Management is as follows 

  • Intravenous infusion of 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate for 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring. It helps to antagonise the cardiac effects.
  • Intravenous regular insulin 10 units followed by 50mL of 50 % dextrose. This helps in shifting the plasma K+ into the cells
  • Nebulisation with β2 agonists such as albuterol or salbutamol are effective. 
  • Cation exchange resins, diuretics and or dialysis are useful to remove the potassium.
